content: The Act titled "Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 2003" amends the Controlled Substances Act. The Controlled Substances Act is amended to define 'anabolic steroid' as any drug related to testosterone, excluding certain substances like estrogens and corticosteroids. Amendments to the Act include criteria for classification and restrictions on scheduling Androstenedione as a controlled substance until a finding is received from the Commissioner of Food and Drugs. The Anabolic Steroids Control Act of 1990 is amended to include recommendations from the Secretary of Health and Human Services regarding compounds containing anabolic steroids. This involves changes to subsections of the Act to address administration to humans or animals and potential for abuse. The United States Sentencing Commission is tasked with reviewing and potentially amending sentencing guidelines for offenses involving anabolic steroids to reflect their seriousness and deter their use. Additionally, they are required to take any necessary actions to carry out this mandate. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to public and nonprofit entities for science-based education programs in schools to highlight the harmful effects of anabolic steroids. Eligible entities must submit an application, with preference given to programs like the Athletes Training and Learning to Avoid Steroids program. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants for education programs on anabolic steroids. Funds will primarily target teachers, principals, coaches, and students. $15,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2004-2009. The National Survey on Drug Use and Health will now include questions about anabolic steroids. $1,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2004-2009 to support this initiative.
